div4.p: And the said parties of the first and of the second parts being unable to agree upon the price to be paid by the Commonwealth for the foregoing lessee and purchase and other privileges, do hereby mutually agree that the same shall be submitted to the arbitrament and award of three disinterested citizens of the Commonwealth, or a majority of them; one of whom shall be chosen by the Commonwealth or her authorized agent, and one by the said Stuart, Buchanan & Co; and the two so chosen to select a third; and if any of the said arbitrators should die, fail or decline to act, his place shall be supplied in the manner in which he was originally selected; and the parties of the first part agree that the sum thus ascertained by the said board, each one of whom shall be sworn before proceeding to act shall be paid in Confederate currency to the said Stuart, Buchanan & Co. whenever the value is to ascertained and possession delivered; and they, the said Stuart,--Co., do agree to receive the same in full discharge of this contract to the said Stuart, Buchanan & Co. by the Commonwealth; but the Commonwealth reserves the right to impress the whole of the property hereby intended to be conveyed, if the said Stuart, Buchanan & Co. shall not in good faith execute this contract in all its parts.
Witness the following signatures:
div4.closer:
R. A. Coghill,
Ch'n of Senate Committee.
B. H. Tomlin
Ch'n of House Committee.
Stu rt Buchanan & Co.

div4.p: The following resolution ratifying the foregoing contract, was submitted by Mr. Coghill:

q.p: Resolved by the General Assembly. That the contract entered into on the 25th of March, 1863. be tween Robert A. Coghill, chairman of the Committee of the Senate of Virginia, and H. B. Tomlin, Chairman of the Committee of the House of Delegates of Virginia, the two committees constituting a joint committee of the General Assembly, on the subject of a supply of and Stuart, Buchanan & Co., in the above words and figures, be and the same is hereby ratified and confirmed.
The same was unanimously adopted and communicated to the House.

The bill to provide for the production and distribution of salt, accompanying the contract, was next taken up and passed, with immaterial amendments, one of which (submitted by Mr. Thompson) does away with a board of supervisors, contemplated in the and gives their powers of control, &c., to the Commissioners of the Board of public Works, at a pay of six dollars per diem.--The bill is of considerable length, and we only present a synopsis of its provisions.

The first section creates the office and officer of a Superintendent of Salt Works, at an annual salary of $5,000, payable quarter yearly, to be elected by the Legislature on joint ballot, removable by the same process, who shall enter into bond with sufficient sureties before the Secretary of the Commonwealth in the penalty of $200,000, conditioned for the faithful discharge of his duties under the act.

The second reaction provides that the Superintendent shall, under the control and management of the Board of Supervisors, (Board of Public Works) manage and dispose of the property, rescind personal, cleared, acquired and herd by Sinort Buchanan & Co., underrate foregoing contract, and to provide all needful supplies for operating the salt works and carrying them on successfully.
The third section, relating to a Hoard of Supervisors, is rendered bull and void by the substitution of the Board of Public Work.

The fourth section empowers the Superintendent to confirm and cent one the existing leases of the four furnaces now leased to Clarkson, Friend Kolly & Gardner, except in the event of the failure of any of these lessees to comply with the terms and provisions of their contracts, in which event he shall resume possession of them, and either relet the furnaces to other parties, or he shall operate them for the benefit of the Commonwealth, as shall pear expedient.
The fifth section gives the Superintendent power to appoint, at his discretion, the following assistants, viz: one deputy Manager, it a salary of $2,000, and one clark, at a salary of $2,00.

The sixth section gives the Superintendent the control of transportation on the Virginia railroads, for the conveyance of supplies to the salt works, and the power, if necessary, to impress the same under the control of the Board.

The seventh section provides for ascertaining the value of the property, real and personal impressed under the act; the Superintendent to appoint or a susessor and the owners another, and the two together a third; the three, or a majority of them to assess the true value of all property impressed.
Upon each certified statement the owner may demand and receive payment from the Treasury of the amount so assessed.
The Superintendent's certificate, improved by the Board, entities the holder whose property may have been purchased or hired, to present the same to the Auditor of Public Accounts and receive payment therefore.

The tenth and eleventh sections relate to the sale and distribution of the salt.
The salt so manufactured is to be sold and distributed to the different counties, towns, and corporations, through duty accredited agents to be appointed by the county and corporation Courts, respectively, at cost, for cash, the Board from time to time to ascertain as near as may be the actual cost of production and distribution and fix the price accordingly, so as to cover such entire cost.
Any plus of salt, after supplying the wants of the people of this State, may be sold to the Confederate Government, or to any of the States, or the people thereof.

The fourteenth section appropriates one million of dollars to carry into effect the provisions of the bill, that an can to be raised by the sale of the registered bonds of the Commonwealth, to be prepared and sold by the Auditor of Public Accounts at the market price, and such additional same as may be paid into the Treasury from time to time from the proceeds of the sale of salt.
The bill was passed on Saturday and reported to the House, where it was understood it would pass without much amendment, and will therefore go into effect immediately.
House of Delegates.--Agreeable to resolution previously adopted, the House, to-day, met at 8 o' clock P. M.
The Tex Bill, under consideration for several days, was again passed upon by the House, and transmitted to the Senate for
The bill to suppress speculation in food was taken up, discussed at some length and laid upon the table.

A Senate bill, declaring what contracts shall be payable in currency, was taken up and considered The bill provides that all contracts entered into for the payment of money, after the 15th day of April, 1863, shall be deemed to be payable in the currency received by the State for State dues, unless otherwise expressly stipulated in the contract; the act to be in force from its passage, and for six months after a treaty of peace between the Confederate States and the United State.
Mr. Seaford moved to amend the bill so as to provide for mailing the contract payable in the currency received by the State at the time of the maturity of such contract, which was agreed to.

Mr. Hunter moved to further amend by inserting the following provision "Provided, however, that this act shall not apply to contracts to be made in counties now occupied by or in the possession of the public enemy."

The proviso was rejected, and the vote referring upon the passage of the bill as amended by Mr. Buford, it was decided in the affirmative.
Ayes 41--38.

The committee of conference, who had under consideration the joint resolution authorizing the Governor to transfer to the Confederate Government the prisoners held by him as hostages for Col. and others, reported back the resolution with an amendment that the Governor shall transfer the same whenever he has satisfactory assurance that they will he retained in confinement by the Confederate authorities until the parties for whom they are held shall be released.
The amendment of the committee was to, and the resolution as amended sent to the Senate for its concurrence.
Senate resolution authorizing the printing of 2,000 copies of the act providing for voting by soldiers and refugees, was passed, Ayes 78
Mr. Mallory moved that when the House adjourn it meet at 9 o'clock A. M., Saturday; to
On motion of Mr. Robinson, of Berkeley, at 11 o'clock, the House adjourned.

div4.p: House of Delegates.--The House met at 10 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Daggett.
A report and resolutions of Senate Committee relative to the sequestration of the property of all a enemies by the Confederate Government, was taken up, read and laid upon the table.

On motion of Mr. Base, the bill increasing the compensation of certain officers of the Penitent was taken up and considered.
The increase of compensation dees not apply to the Superintendent, and the blanks in the bill were filled up as follows; 1st Assistant Superintendent, $1,000 per all other assistants $900, Surgeon, $1,000; Clerk, $1,000.

Mr. Marye offered a provise, that the increased compensation should continue for one year after the term nation of the existing war and no longer, which was agreed to, and the bill, as thus perfected, passed 17.
The General appropriation Bill, reported from the Senate with amendments was considered by the House, and after a few slight disagreements and amendments was returned to the Senate for its action.

A message was received from the Senate announcing the passage, by that body, of a bill "to provide for the production and distribution of salt," reported from the joint committee with amendments and asking the concurrence of the House in the same.
On motion of Mr. Barbour, the salt bill was taken up, discussed and amended until 3 o'clock, as which hour the their was vacated until o'clock.

div3.p: was act in Friday, having Monday.
House of --Hours Met at 11 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Mr. Peterkin.
The Speaker laid before the House, bill of the Senate to increase the allowance for mileage to officers of the navy and agents traveling under Referred to Committee on Naval Affairs.

Also, Senate bill to it crease the pay of masters mates in the navy.
Referred to the same committee.
Mr. Ketner, of La., from the Committee of Ways and Means, reported back the annexed resolution, which was agreed to:
Resolved That the President be requested to cause to be submitted to Congress estimates of appropriations for the first half of the next fiscal year.

Mr. Clarke, of Ga, arose to what he said he considered a privilege question.
At the last session of Congress a bill was passed increasing the pay of district tax collectors to four hundred dollars. He had in his possession a latter which showed that the chief collector of the war tax in Virginia was levying black mail upon the sub collectors of the State by charging each of them $10 for his influence in securing the passage of the bill referred to. He know nothing of the position of the gentleman in question.
In order, however, to vindicate the integrity of the members of this body he thought the matter should be investigated
Mr. Garnett, of Va., called for the reading of the letter.

Mr. Clarke then read an extract of a letter from the tax collector in Roanoke county, conferring a power of attorney upon a gentleman in Richmond to collect his allowance, and directing him to hand over ten dollars of the money to Col. Garnett as a present for his influence in getting the passage of the bill.

Mr. Garnett said that the gentleman aided to in the letter (Col. H. F Garnett,) was a constituent of his, and a distant relative, and he believed as incapable of anything dishonorable as any gentleman on this floor.
He hoped there would be an investigation, feeling satisfied that the charges would be refuted as so hers made in this Hall against distinguished citizens of this State had been.
Mr. Parkins, of La., was of opinion that the matter was one requiring investigation, and he therefore moved the following resolution:

Resolved. That a committee of five be appointed by the Chair to investigate the charges against the integrity of the chief collector of the war tax of the State of Virginia, in relation to the passage of a bill increasing the compensation of collectors of the war tax.
After some further discussion, Mr. Clapp of Miss, offered the following as a substitute for Mr. Perkins's resolutions.

Resolved, That a committee of five be appointed to investigate an alleged improper it fluence exercised by the chief collector of the war tax in the State of Virginia to procure the passage of a bill by this House.
Mr. Garland, of Ark., moved to lay both resolutions upon the table.
Mr. Clarke demanded the ayes and noes on this motion, which were ordered, with the following result — ayes 38 noce 48.
The substitute of Mr. Clapp was then adopted.

Mr. Chilton, of Ala., moved to reconsider the vote.
There was nothing in the extract of the letter read which, in his opinion, reflected upon any member of this body.
He was willing, however, to vote for the resolution to investigate the conduct of the chief collector of Virginia.

Mr. Davis, of Miss., sustained the motion to reconsider.
Be would vote for the original resolution, and if, on investigation, it should turn out that any member had been influenced in his vote upon the bill referred to, it would then be time to pursue the matter further.
The motion to reconsider prevailed, and the resolution of Mr. Perkins was adopted

Mr. M of South Carolina moved to suspend the rules to allow him to report back from the Committee on Military Affairs.
Senate bill for the discharge of certain civil officers from the military service of the Confederate States.
The rules were suspended and the bill taken up.

Mr. Chilton, of Alabama, moved to amend by striking out the following: Provided, that no person elected or appointed to any civil offices shall be discharged under unless the office to when he may be elected or appointed is such an office as entitles the officer filling it, under exemption laws now existing, or which may hereafter exist, to exemption from military service in the armies of the Confederate States.
This motion prevailed, and the bill as thus an ended was passed.
The House then resumed the consideration of the bill to provide for the assessment and collection of taxes which was completed.

div3.head: Soldier drowned.
div3.p:
--On Friday last Coroner Sar was summoned to hold an inquest over the body of Thomas Kelleher, whose body was found by the Coroner lying on a dray, west of and directly opposite to the arch of the First Market House.--From the inquiries instituted by the Coroner it appeared that the deceased, while attempting, on thursday night, to cross the bridge that spans Shockoe creek at the painting acted, had fallen into the water, and was drowned before assistance could reach him. At the time Kellcher fell inches river was much swollen by the melting of the snow in the mountains, and Shockoe creek had risen above the bridge and covered it. The deceased boarded at Pat Maroney's, on 18th above Marshall street and was a discharged soldier, belonging formerly to Company I, 17th Virginia regiment, (the O'Connor Guards, from Alexandria, Va.) He was known as a peaceful and quiet citizen, and in the army as a good acuter.
He had no relations in this part of Virginia.
The Coroner took charge of his affects, which consisted of $75 68 in money, a few postage stamps, and a silver watch.
The body was buried at the expense of the decedent, and an inquest was not deemed necessary.

div3.head: Attempted Escapes.
div3.p:
--Capt. A. Webster, of Pierpoint's army who was condemned a short time since by court-martial to be hang on the 3d of April for violating his parole of honor, attempted to escape from Castle Thunder on Friday night, and was nearly successful in the endeavor.
He had been put in the hospital on the ground of indisposition and while lying in bed, with a sentinel at the foot of it and himself adorned with suckle and wrist irons, suddenly leaped out, clear of all encumbrances, and made for a window.
The sentinel shaped his piece at the retreating fugitive, the cap only exploding.
Webster gained the eastern window of the third story, leaped out, and was fired at by the outside sentinel as he descended to the ground.
The shot did not take affect, and, on reaching the ground, Webster made off as fast as a badly sprained ankle would allow.
An alarm being raised he was soon caught and conducted back to his old quarters, and a double guard placed over him. This man, Webster, possesses a peculiar faculty of clearing himself of irons.
It is said be can unto any placed on him by the use of a small stick.
Whether he can undo himself from the gallows next Friday remains to be seen.

div3.head: Negro killed.
div3.p:
--A negro man on board the steamboat West Point, at Rocketts, was killed Saturday evening under the following circumstances: He and a comrade bad found an old musket aboard, which they did not know we loaded.
They began mutually to carry each other through the manual of arm. Deceased had gone through his part to the satisfaction of his comrade, and took his stand as drill sergeant.
When he gave the command "ready, fire, " the darkey who held the fire-arm pulled the trigger, the gun loded. and the ball passing through the drill sergeant's body death was the immediate consequence Coroner was summoned, but, on inquiring into the circumstances, did not deem an inquest necessary.

div3.head: Abolition prisoners.
div3.p:
--Sixteen Abolitionists were brought from the West to the Libby prison on thanksgiving day. On Saturday thirty-two were brought from Staunton.
Included in the lot was a deserter from an Ohio regiment, and one from the 1st Massachusetts cavalry, who left his comrades in Moorefield, Hardy county; also, the following citizens, charged with disloyalty, viz: J W Butler, Leesburg; E. Wilnite, Hardy county; Wm W. Maxwell Wyoming county; F Waroax.
of Williamsburg.
Twelve Yankee sailors, part of the crow of the steamer Columbia, also arrived on Saturday from Wilmington N. C. No flag of trues had arrived from the Yankees up to yesterday.
On Wednesday 1,500 Abolitionists are expected here from the southwest Included in the number are 300 commissioned officers and two Brigadier Generals

Twelve prisoners of war, from the West, were brought to Richmond on the 16th instant.
They named from Chattanooga but were captured singly or in pairs, in various places near Gen. Braggs army.
The 1,000 Yankees now here at the cost of the Government, cost $1,50 per day to them.
They will be sent home the first available opportunity.

div3.head: Indicted.
div3.p:
--Shortly after the battles around Richmond, where many a brave man attended by his blood his devotion to the common cause, the Provost Marshal of Richmond sent cut agents to gather in all the decries of the battles in the shape of blankets, muskets, etc. In pursuance of such orders they visited a number of counties, and gathered many valuables left by the retreating Yankees, which were brought to Richmond.
Among other officers, detective Logan McCoull was sent on this service, and he has been indicted in about twenty cases by the Grand Jury of Charles City county.
In one instance for reclaiming two Yankee muskets held by a citizen.

div3.head: Stealing coal
div3.p:
--The coal merchants of Richmond complain that they have been melted considerably lately at night by gangs of boys, who prowl about the yards and make a regular business of loading themselves with large lumps and leaving as speedily unpassable.
Some of the declares have lost, on an average, $25 worth of coal each night.
The police will no doubt take to put an and to the of the mouthful Bohemians.

div3.head: Citizen shot
div3.p:
--Mr S. W. Grubbs, of Manchester, was shot on thursday evening, and instantly killed, by an soldier belonging to Hood's division.
The deceased had given the soldier no cation, save in being before him, and therefore an object on which to exercise his warlike feelings.

div3.head: Military prison.
div3.p: --The following arrivals were booked at the military prison on Saturday last, viz: Patrick McGuire, company B. 6th Louisiana, charged with dictating the 24th article of war; J. H. Smarr, a Yankee spy, to be court-martialed; Johnson, copy, sent from Staunton; Thomsen is a recaptured Yankee prisoner, and fourteen men fide sentence of court martial.

Nation --Robert Ryan a member of Capt artillery company station at Marton hill, was down by a footpad with a sling shot on Saturday evening in and of which he had on his at times.
Ryan was very badly injured, in addition to being despoiled of his money.

div3.head:
Mayer's Court.
Saturday March 28th.
div3.p: --Cerdy Adams was brought up and arraigned for committing an unprovoked assault on Harriet, his wife.--The Mayor held him to ball in to keep the price and the name amount to appear before the Hustings Court and answer the charge of made
Rudolph Lurrain was required to give security to keep the peace on the charge of getting corned and smashing in one of the windows of E. Y. Cannon's law office.
John Costilla Holland was examined and sent on to the Hustings Court for stealing $31 from Pleasant M. Bonley.

div3.head: Arrest.
div3.p: --Martha, slave of R. H. L. Tighe, was arrested by the police yesterday and caged for examination before the Mayor to day, on the charge of stealing a one hundred dollar note from her master.

div3.head: Very latest from the North.
div3.p: --New York dates of the 27th are received.
Burnside has assumed command of the department of the Ohio.

Skirmishing took place on the 24th and the day before, between the Federal cavalry and the Rebel advance, south of the Kentucky river.
The Rebel advance is variously estimated at from 3,500 to 10,000.
Confidence is felt in the ability of the Federal to repel the invasion.
The non-arrival of the Frankfort train at Louisville, on the 26th, had caused much anxiety.
A dispatch from Memphis, dated the 26th, says that Farragut's vessel had recaptured the Indianola at Hard Times Bend, without resistance.

The fight at Brentford Station, Tennessee, resulted in a Yankee loss of 15 killed, wounded and missing. Rebel loss the same number, but left 42 prisoners. Var. Dorn conducted the fight with 15,000 men. another dispatch, received at Philadelphia, represents the Rebel loss much greater than that above, and the Federal loss less.
A rebel deserter, at Murfreesboro', says the wife of Gen. B gg died at Tullahoma on the 23d.
The rebel schooner Lightning was captured by the Richville two hours out from Port Royal.
The Willey amendment and Constitution of the new State of Virginia were ratified on the 25th by an almost unanimous vote.
Lincoln and his friends at Washington were never more encouraged since the beginning of the rebellion than now.

Guthrie has made an earnest protestation to Lincoln concerning the removal of all the Kentucky troops from that State and exposing the people to more rebel raids.
Burnside's corps will fill the vacancy in Kentucky.

Gold in New York, Thursday, was 139 Exchange, 152.
Cotton, 55a65. Sales of 750 bales.

div4.head: From Europe.
div4.p: The Etna, with dates to the 12th, has arrived News unimportant.
The Herald says the idea of French intervention may new be considered at an end.

The fine steamer Banshee, lying at Queenstown lately, is preparing either to run the blockade, or for direct service under the rebel Government.
She is steel plated, and said to be very fast.

div3.head: Successful cavalry raid by Gen, Forrest.

div4.p: The following official dispatch was received Saturday at the War Department:

--To Gen S. Cooper, A. and I.
G:--Gen. Van-Dorn reports that Gen Forrest made a successful visit to Brentwood with his division.
He burnt the bridge and took all the property and arms, and captured 860 prisoners, including 35 officers.
He lost three killed and five wounded.

div4.head: [another Dispatch.]
div4.p:
--the Rebel has received the following dated Columbia.
25th: General Forrest captured yesterday at Brentwood, nine miles in the rear of 800 prisoners, with their arms, ammunition, &c. He destroyed a large house of commissary stores, burnt the railroad bridge, tone up the track and captured 17 covered wagons.

div3.head: From Kentucky, &c.
div3.p:
--The Memphis Bulletin is received.
Louisville is to be fortified, and citizens sympathising with the Confederacy paroled.
The Hetty Gilmore and crow had captured more Confederates on Green river.
The Confederates bad occupied Owenten, Ky. The sale of firearms had been prohibited at Indianapolis.

A Yankee dispatch says Fort Pemberton cannot be attacked by infantry.
The Confederate force there is estimated at 6,000.
It is stated that the fort once passed, no danger is apprehended between there and Yazoo City.
The next news it was supposed would be flattering.
Five small boats had arrived in the Coldwater with reinforcements.
The position of the enemy was unknown.
The Mississippi was falling at Memphis.

div4.p: --Nothing additional from the front today.

The official report from Gen. Morgan of his late fight states that it lasted six hours, and that he drove the enemy two miles, and they were heavily reinforced and held their position.
Morgan says his loss in officers was heavy.

div4.head: [another account.]
div4.p:
--The Chronicle has a special dispatch from McMinnville, Tenn., March 27, which says that Gen. Morgan had a revere fight wish the Federates near Milton, on the 20th, which lasted five hours. The Federal were resulted and driven 8 miles. Our loss was 15 killed and 75 wounded Federal loss about twice that number.
They advanced in order to draw our forces from Liberty, but they were compelled to fall back to Murfreesboro'.

div3.head: From Tennessee.
div3.p:
--The report of the capture of the Federal Gene all Carter's brigade by Humphrey Marshall is not confirmed.
The Register has received the following dispatch:

q.p:
"Wartrace, March 27.--There is daily skirmishing on the Shelbyville pike.
The enemy's videttes are four and a half rises from Murfreesboro', and their pickets are at Stone's river.
It is believed that the enemy is moving a heavy force on our left flank, in the direction of Columbia.
The object is doubtless to form a connection with Grant, and thus cause the Confederates to fall back to Bridgeport.
The enemy are devastating the country, burning fences, killing stock, forcing off negroes and stealing generally.
A train ran off the track between this point and Shelbyville.
No lives lost."

div3.head: From Vicksburg.
div3.p:
--A special to the Appeal, from Vicksburg, says: At 5 o'clock this morning four boats were seen advancing towards the upper batteries.
A vigorous fire was opened upon them, driving back two, when the other two passed under a raking fire, almost every shot taking effect.
One received a shot in her steam chest, compelling her crew to desert her, and in 15 minutes she filled and Part of her crow escaped to the opposite there.
The boat that escaped is supported to be the Benton, badly disabled.
One shot penetrated her steam drum, disabling her so badly that the Albatross came up to tow her out of danger of our gunboats.

div3.head: From Fort Pemberton.
div3.p:
--The Jackson Appeal says the intelligence that the enemy has appeared again in front of Fort Pemberton is confirmed.
On Monday afternoon firing took place, but the result is unknown.

div3.head: Married,
div3.p: On the 4th of March, 1863, at the residence of the bride's maid
Paycttaville papers please copy. *

div3.head: Died,
div3.p: At the Chimborazo Hospital, on the 19th of March, Corporal P J of company K. 61st Virginia regiment in the 17th year of his age, after a short but painful illness.

He bore his sickness with Christian fortitude and resignation.
He leaves a devoted wife and one child and numerous friends to mourn their irreparable loss.
But they mourn not as those who have no hops.
Petersburg papers please copy.

div3.head: Servants for Hire.
div3.p:
--Two good Cook Women, without encumbrance of good character, and also one Woman, with one child, who it a good Home Servant, and a superior Noble and a plain Seamstress.
Apply to me at I H. Walke's store Main street.

div3.head: Negroes for sale.
div3.p: --Two or more valuable Negroes will be sold at public auction in the town of Greensboro', N C, on Thursday, the 2d day of april proz.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay one hundred dollars reward for the apprehension and delivery to me, or to Messrs P. M. Tabb & Son of my slave Lucy Ann — generally called Lucy — who absconded from my house, corner of Clay and 6th streets, some two months since.
She is about twelve or fourteen years old, very thin and black, stutters sometimes in talking, and had on when she left a yellowish cotton dress and an old she which she wore ever her head, in lien of a bonnet.
She has been seen in the streets several times since she left my house, and is doubtless lurking somewhere about the city.
I had reason to believe that she was at first harbored by some person or persons residing north of Leigh street and west of sixth street but she has probably changed her quarters, as she was last down Cary street, near 5th street, with a tin bucket.
If any person is employing her in ignorance of her being a runaway slave it will be well for him to give immediate information.

div3.head: Twenty five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--A negro man named Jack.
frequently called John, belonging to my aunt.
Miss Frances A E let, has been missing for the past two or three weeks from the city Gas Works, where he was hired in January last.
He is about 20 years old, black, short, and stoutly and has a small piece broken off from one of his upper front teeth.
He has a wife named Milly Crew, a free woman, living on 2d, between Baker and Duval streets. I believe he is lurking somewhere about the city, or perhaps at some of the camps or batteries in its vicinity, and will pay the above reward for his apprehension.
div3.closer:
Temple Bliett
At Treasury Department,
Custom house building mh 30--1t*

div3.head: Runaway--$00 reward.
div3.p:
--Dick, about twenty years of age, five feet eight or nine in height, not very stout, dark brown color, in his right ankle from a recent attack of dropay in the left my house between 12 at night of Friday and 6 o'clock Saturday morning. It is supposed he is recreated about the city or attempting to make his way North viz Norfolk or the Peninsula.
The above reward of $100 will be paid for his delivery to me in Richmond.

div3.head: Twenty five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway, from the farm of John C Taylor deed, on the Brook Plank Road three miles north of Richmond, a man named Dick.
He is about 5 feet 6 inches in height, gingerbread color; he has a lump on the shoulders, and walks very careless and He left about the time Hood's division passed through Henrico, and may be with them.
I will pay the above reward for him if delivered in Richmond, or on the farm in Henrico
div3.closer:
Tremanda T Taylor.
Adm's of Jno O Taylor dec'd. mb 30--6t*

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Run away, from the residence of Mr. Lowis Doughty, on Hill, about six weeks ago, Mary a good looking girl, of bright complexion, about 20 years old; badly dressed at that time; she is of medium size, and stammers some when spoken to quick. --She is supposed to be somewhere about the city.
I will give the above reward if she is placed in the county jail of Henrico.
div3.closer:
Geo Delanson,
Sheriff of Henrico, and
Asm'r of Marous A Tinsley, dec'd. mh --ts

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 76, page 3.
Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 76, page 4.

div3.head: To the people of Northwestern Virginia.
div3.p:
Fellow Citizens.--The present war has now reached a stage at which every candid mind must be convinced that it will soon result in the complete establishment of the separate independence of the Confederate States.
After two years of war, in which the North has lost several hundred thousand men, and spent more than a thousand million dollars, the Confederacy remains unconquered.
It is now more able to resist than it was in the beginning, comparing its strength with the power of the enemy.
It has larger and better armies, with more copious materials of war than it had a year ago. It still repulses early every advance of the enormous levies of the North.
It has already displayed more strength and acquired more glory than other countries which have been independent for ages.
If its achievements have been attended with large expenditures of blood and treasure, yet the capacity of such a people as ours to carry on war can never be exhausted while the war is to resist subjugation.
On the contrary, the North, which fights for conquest, must find its warlike resources practically exhausted whenever it become clear that conquest is impossible in a war waged by the North for the subjugation of the South, the failure of the North is the complete triumph of the South.
That triumph is at hand.

That result appears certain to us, who know the spirit and resources of the Confederacy.
Even you, who have been separated from the South, and have learned the events of the war mainly from Northern sources, must have corrected their boastful bulletins of victories by the confessed results of campaigns.
You know, for example, how many "grand armies" have been sent to take Richmond, and Low many victories they have claimed; but you have seen the same armies always return shattered, decimated, disgraced.
You know that Richmond remains undefiled by the foot of a conqueror.

We have met with some disasters.
Others may befall us. They would not discourage us. Even if Richmond, or Charleston, or Vicksburg, or any other city were to fall, there would still remain to us between the Atlantic and the Rio Grande a vast country and an unconquerable people.
Partial successes of the enemy, wherever obtained, must at length be abandoned by the remnants of invading armies, glad to escape from a country which they may ravage, but cannot subdue.

The North can never conquer the South--Neither will the South ever consent to a restoration of the Union.
An inhuman attempt to subjugate a brave, free, enlightened, Christian people can never be forgiven or forgotten.
The atrocities of the North in prosecuting the war, and a desperate attempt to invoke servile insurrection, have placed a fiery gulf of hatred between the two countries.
The separation, which was forced by fanaticism, has been confirmed by ferocious folly.
It is not the South which will have to regret the consequences.

As certainly as the atrocious scheme of subjugation is destined to fall, just so certainly will every inch of the soil of Virginia remain under her jurisdiction.
The entire South will be conquered, or all Virginia will be free.
By column resolves the Confederate and State Governments stand pledged never to surrender any part of the State.
They will be prompted by every motive of interest and of honor to redeem the pledge at all hazards.

During this war our new Government could not keep large armies constantly in Northwestern.
Virginia without neglecting points of defence.
Vexatious raids have usually been avoided.
But our battles have been fought as well for the ultimate liberation of the Pan Handle as for the independence of all the Confederate States.
Event may yet take a different course even in this war. Hereafter such preparations will be made that in future wars the brave and hardy men of Northwestern Virginia, backed by the most warlike nation on the globe, will more probably become invaders than victims of invasion.
They would be in greater danger on the Northern than they would be on the Southern side of the boundary.

We congratulate you upon the certainty that our section of the State will remain with Virginia and with the Confederacy.
A large majority, we believe, will rejoice in this assurance.
Your interests are with the South.
In the Confederacy, our section of Virginia, so full of all natural elements of wealth, will become one of the most prosperous regions of the continent.
With the North it would dwindle under the shadow of rival and stronger sections.

In the South we have maintained free institutions throughout this tremendous struggle, while the Government has needed the largest powers, and the people would have acquiesced in many stretches of authority in order to defend their political existence, their property, their families and their lives.
We have thus proved that liberty may flourish among us for ever.
The North, merely for the hope of enslaving us, has given up, one after another, the most sacred safeguards of constitutional freedom, and has shown itself incompetent to preserve free institutions.
You will be glad to enjoy liberty with the South rather than endure despotism with the North.

When this unequal struggle began, it might have been expected that the borders of Virginia, and especially the Northwest, would, for a time, be overflowed by the armed populations of the North.
It was not to have been expected that a civilized nation would brutalize war by such barbarities as you have suffered and witnessed.
It is hardly credible that any among you would have made themselves agents of the invaders to oppress their fellow-citizens by setting up a petty Government under the protection of foreign bayonets.
We do not address ourselves to those who have eagerly engaged with the enemy to subjugate or to dismember our venerable Commonwealth.--They have chosen to abide the event of a war in which they have taken the part of traitors, and they must abide it. To those among you, who, rather than betray the State, have suffered oppression from usurpers and invaders with martyr-like constancy, we tender the tribute of our cordial sympathy and profound admiration.
They deserve to be ranked with those other citizens of Northwestern Virginia, who, on every battle field of the State, from Great Bethel to Fredericksburg, have fought with heroic courage in the cause of liberty. --These gallant men, and those who great home, have boldly maintained the right of the people of the Northwest to wear the illustrious name of Virginians in spite of the treason which some have committed.

If you have not all acted with equal firmness, we are gratified to believe (as we have many reasons for believing) that a large majority of the citizens of Northwestern Virginia have cherished a loyal attachment to the State, and that they abhor treason and traitors.
We know how to make due allowance for the cruel necessities of your situation.
While some of us were able to retire to places where we could serve the cause of the South, and several thousand have joined our armies, it is just to remember that a whole community so great as ours could not withdraw into the interior; nor could they alone resist the powerful States on their borders.
Many were hampered by poverty, or charged with the care of families, or detained at home by other obstacles which could not be overcome.
Being compelled to remain, their submission could be enforced by arms.
Mere submission to irresistible force will not be imputed to them as a crime.
Voluntary and corrupt complicity with treason can never be excused by any circumstances.

We are proud to know that a large majority of the people in Northwestern Virginia have always refused to vote at the elections ordered by the usurped Government.
Situated as you have been, it was the most effectual protest you could offer against that capitation.
We advise you to persevere in that course, unless, upon some special occasion, you can deliver a united and affective vote which cannot be construed as a friendly recognition of usurped authority; as, for example, to protest against a dismemberment of the State.
Without inciting you to rash and vain resistance to overwhelming force, we advice you to make a manly avowal of your loyalty.
We invite all the young men who can to unite with the renowned armies of the South.
No man should willingly so great a duty at the defence of his country's independence.
No man of spirit can be a careless spectator of the meat remarkable straggle for constitutional freedom in all time.
In future ages it will be the boast of the proudest in the lead that they are descended from the heroes of this war.

We you all, young and old, to cherish the sentiment of loyalty.
Encourage one another, Suffer with fortitude what you have to suffer.
He vigilant, resolute, and hold when your opportunity comes.
Rest assured that
the invaders will be expelled and the power of your oppresses will be overthrown.

Ran off from Hospital no. 12, George, about 23 years of age, 5 feet 6 or 8 inches high, smooth black skin, tolerably long hair, and good teeth; thrust his head when spoken to and you look him in the eye. He has a pleasing face, and is very likely.
Also, Jim. a stout, weather man, about 33 years old, 5 feet 4 or 6 inches high, not very black, thin beard about the mouth and chin, rather slow of speech, and spears rather sullen.
One hundred dollars reward for each of them.--Reference — Dr Thom, Hospital No. 12, or Mr Lewis H Piggott, Chimborazo.
div3.closer:
Chas M Rusfard,
James City county. mh 27--3t*

div3.head: Ran away
div3.p:
--$100 reward.--Ran away from the Danville and Greensboro' Railroad, about the 7th of this month, (March,) two negroes, named Emanuel and Dennis Emanuel is about thirty-five years of age, five feet ten inches in height, of a dark gingerbread color.
Dennis is about fifteen years of age, of a rather brighter color than Emennet, with quite a pleasing countenance when spoken to, it is thought they are aiming to get back to Caroline county, but may to pass themselves off as free and attach themselves to the army, or remain lurking in the neighborhood of Richmond.
The above reward will be given for their delivery to either of the under signed, near Rappahannock Academy, or secured so that we get them again.

div3.head: Runaway in jail.
div3.p:
--Was committed to the jail of Louisa county, as a runaway, on the 30th day of July. 1862, a small negro boy, who says his name is Charles, and that he belongs to Lieut West, of Louisiana.
He appears to be about ten or twelve years old it four feet high, of a brown color, had on when committed to jail a blue sack coat.
brown Jeans pantaloons, and a blue cloth cap. The owner of said boy is required to come forward and prove his property, pay oberges, and take him away, or he will be disposed of as the law diree's.
div3.closer:
James R GOOCHSheriff and
Jailor of Louisa county. mh 16--1aw6w*

div3.head: Five hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay $500 reward for the apprehension and delivery to me, in Richmond, of my house boy Albert, who absconded from my residence, corner of 5th and Grace streets, on the morning of the 20th inst. Albert is of a dark gingerbread color, 27 years old, about 5 feet 7 inches high, is well formed, quick and active in his motion, and we are rather a glum countenance when in conversation.
He was raised by Mr Isaac A Goddin, and has two brothers and other relations in this city.

Fifty dollars reward will be paid for the arrest and confinement in jail, so that I can get her, of my negro woman Celia.
She left me in Manchester.
Monday, March 16, 1863, about 2 o'clock in the afternoon, and is believed to be in or near Manchester or the city of Richmond.
Cella is about 30 years old, but looks older; is a little under the medium height; very stoutly made; of a ginger-bread color; has thick but remarkably narrow eyebrows; looks somewhat grum, and talks rapidly.
She had on when she left a home-made linsey dress; a gay-colored, double blanket shawl and a quilted hood.
She carried a bundle of clothes with her. Address Jos Wells, Manchester, Va, or she subscriber.
div3.closer:
Chas B Tebes,
Richmond city. mh 23--5t*

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, about the 1st of the present month, (March,) 1863, my negro man Dill Rd. He is 24 years of age, of rather dark complexion, and about six feet in height.
He is very intelligent and sprightly, and can read and write He has been recently hired in Richmond, where he has many acquaintances, and I should not be surprised if he is now there, on his way to the Yankees, or he may have taken some other route for their lines.
I will pay fifty dollars if he is taken in this city and confined in jail, or one hundred if taken out of Lynchburg and lodged in any other jail, so that I can get him again.

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the apprehension of my negro man Anderson, who ranaway in the city of Richmond on the 13th inst. Anderson is about 20 years old, black; well formed, and about 5 feet 7 inches high.
Has no scars or marks on him. The above reward will be paid for his apprehension and delivery to Hill, Dickinson & Co.

div3.head: Three hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Left the residence of Col Moore, on 5th street, on Saturday, the 7th inst, a servant boy named Severly Valentine.
The said Beverly it the property of Mrs Judge Beverly Tucker, of Williamsburg.
He is a copper-colored mulatto about 5½ feet high, very slender in person, brown eyes, and hair inclined to our. His demeanor it remarkably modest and quiet.
When spoken to be looks rather intimidated, but soon recovers him self.
He wore, when last seen, a brown coat, with brass buttons, (he always wears his coat buttoned at the waist,) a red flannel shirt, with blue trimmings, and a blue military cap, lined with a stripped and white material.
The above reward will be paid for his apprehension and delivery at the corner of 5th and Cary streets, Richmond Va, or lodged in jail in said city.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the arrest and delivery in Richmond of a negro calling himself Isaiah.
He is about 5 feet 4 inches high, well made, and weighs near 140 lbs, has an intelligent face, of a dark ginger bread color, and is 19 years old. He ran away from the Bells Isle Works about four weeks ago and is supposed to be lurking in or near the city — The above reward will be paid for his delivery in any neighboring county jail or at the office of the Old Dominion Iron and Nail Works Company in Richmond.

div3.head: Deserted
div3.p:
--Private William H Banks of Parker's Battery, on or about the 7th inst, near Chesterfield Station, Richmond and Fredericksburg railroad.
Said Banks took with him a horse, and it is supposed is trying to make his way to Maryland, his native State, through our lines at or near Fredericksburg.
He is about 5 feet 10 inches high, light hair, complexion, and eyes, defective front teeth, and stammers a little.
Thirty dollars will be given for his arrest and lodgment in some secure place.
div3.closer:
Wm W Parker,
Capt Co C, Light Artillery,
Col E P Alexander's Bat'n mh 12--cod4t*

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward
div3.p:
--I will pay the above reward for the apprehension and delivery, or confinement in jail, of my man George Rucker.
who ran away in December last and was last heard of at the farm of Mr Morson, in Goochland, where his wife lives.
George is well known in Fishmond and on the Canal, having been Captain of a freight boat for twenty years He about 50 years of age, 5 feet 8 inches high, ginger bread color, and has remarkably short hair, closely napt.
div3.closer:
Clifford Cabell.
Greenway P. O. Nelson co. Va. mh 11--10t*

div3.head: Twenty five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, in the city of Richmond, between 17th and 18th streets, on Main at., my Negro Man, William.
The said William is about 20 years of age, black, and well built He is well acquainted in the city of Richmond, and it is highly probable he is lurking about the city.
I will give the above reward for the delivery of the said negro to me, or secured in jail an that I can get him again
Ranaway From the U S lot, Bacon's Quarter Fresh, about the 1st of February, two negro men, named Delaware and Bin.

Delaware was hired from P. M. Tabb & Son and belongs to Mrs Jno Mutter, of Hanover county and was hired last year to Mr George Turner.
He is a sort of bricklayer, and is probably doing job work about the city.
He is about 5 feet 7 or 8 inches high, copper colored, and about 25 years of age.

Ben was hired from W S Phillips, and belongs King Graves, of Chesterfield county.
He is black about 5 feet 9 or 10 inches high, and about 24 years old. I understand he is a kind of huckster around the markets and the city, which occupation he may now be engaged in.
A liberal reward will be paid for the delivery of the above named negroes to me, or confined in jail in the city, so that they can be procured.
div3.closer:
W S Wood,
Major and Q M Army Transportation,
Bacon's Quarter Branch, Richmond. mh 7--ts

div3.head: Ran away
div3.p:
--Ran away from the service the James River and Kanawha Company, about two weeks ago, a negro boy named Sam, the property of Col Wm P Munford.
Sam's parents reside in the city, and he is well known here and is familiar himself with all parts of the city, and is no doubt here.
He is about five feet six inches tall, of a brown color, round face amati and pleasant countenance.
He has the rheumatism and is lame in his left knee, which he cannot conceal when walking.
The company will pay $25 reward for the arrest of Sam and his confinement in Cary Street Jail, where I can get him.

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p: --Ran away, my negro man, Henry, about 5 feet 8 inches high, ginger-cake color, very full head of hair, about 30 years of age; had on when he went off a full suit of home-made clothes and a blue Yankee overcoat, and a white slouched hat. I will give a reward of $50 if he is delivered to me at my residence in Goochland county, or if he is lodged in jail so that I yet him again.

div3.head: Runaway
div3.p:
--$50 reward.--Ran away from the subscriber, in Henrico county, my servant, Smith.
Said negro is about 30 years old, black, polite when spoken to. He has lost part of one car; was purchased in Richmond last January, and came from Fauquier county.
I will give the above reward for his apprehension and delivery to me or his confinement in jail so that I get him again.

div3.head:
Camp 8th Louis Ana near Hemilson's evening.
March 22d, 1863
div3.p: Fifty dollars reward — A reward of $50 each will he paid for the apprehension and delivery of the following named deserters of company I, 8th Louisiana Volunteers, to the Captain of the company in the camp of the 8th Louisiana of lodge them in any of the military prisons of Richmond or Lynchburg:

Terrence Shields, a native of Ireland 5 feet 9 inches high, dark brown hair 31 years of age gray eyes, left eye cut open in the lower inside her Said Shields deserted on the 7th of September 1862 at Frederick City, Md.

Daniel Ryan.
a native of Ireland, 19 years of age, 5 feet 10 inches high, dark hair light complexion, Said Ryan deserted on the 10th of September, at Frederick City, Md. shields and Ryan are supposed to be in the cavalry service.

L W Snyler a Texas, 27 years of age, 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high, light complexion blue eyes; deserted the company at Jackson, Miss, and joined an infirmary corps in Richmond.
He is supposed to be in some regiment now in Northern Virginia

Jeperot, a native of Louisiana, 21 or 25 years of age 5 feet 9 or 10 inches high black hair, black eyes, and dark complexion.
Belongs to cavalry company, now in or near Richmond.

div3.head: Deserters
div3.p:
--Priv Jas Riley, of co Virginia Battalion.
He is about 5th 10 inches it height, dark hair and dark complexion deserted on the 15th July, 1862, from hospital in Richmond

Priv J Heloves, of co D, 22d Virginia Battalion.
received as a substitute 1st and deserted Feb. 2d; is forty six years of age, 5 feet 5 inches is height, blue eyes, brown hair, and light complexion.

Sergt E R King, of co D, 22d Virginia Battalion, is about 6 feet 1 inch in height complexion, and blue eyes.
He is in the vicinity of in Mecklenburg county Va.
Thirty dollars reward will be paid for the arrest and confinement of each or either of the above described deserters
div3.closer:
Wm G Jackson.
Capt Co D, 22d Va Bat Gen Field's Brigade,
Camp Grege, Caroline co, Va mh 27--2t*

div3.head: Two hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Beney large substitute for of Nothaway, has absented himself and the above reward will be paid any one who will arrest and confine him in any of the prisons at Richmond or Petersburg.
His description is following 47 gray eyes, dark 5 feet 9 inches high a native of Germany
div3.closer:
Th
Recruiting officer, 1st Lieut 1st Va. Cen by found at the officer of on
Bank st, between 11th and 2ndwh 27--4t*

div3.head: Hdq'rs 1st Reg T Va March
div3.p: Thirty dollars reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery to these headquarters, or confinement in one of the Confederate States prisons, for each of the following named privates:
Company James Edwards, sandy hair, ruddy complexion 5 feet 9 inches high 38 years old from Cumberland co

Company G--Jr Mahone blue eyes light half light complexion 5 feet 7½ inches high from Richmond.
Geo Walters, gray eyes dark hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 6 inches old from Germany.
Wm Underwood hair light eyes, fair complexion 5 feet 8 inches high years old, from Dinwiddie John Foley dark hair fair complexion, 6 feet high 40 years old from Ireland
Company H. W R Joseph, blue eyes light half light complexion, 5 feet 7 inches high 20 years old from Richmond

Company I--Wm H Moore dark eyes, dark hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 11 inches high 38 years old from Halifax C H Yancey, hazel eyes light hair dark complexion 5 feet 7 inches high.
38 years old from Halifax R O Meredith gray eyes dark hair, light complexion, 5 feet 7 inches high 22 years old from Richmond, W C Taliaferro dark eyes dark complexion, 5 feet 4 inches high, 22 years old from Hanover.
Company H--W S Wood gray eyes light hair fair complexion, 5 feet 10½ inches high, 21 years old from Henry co.
Company G. John R Lord dark eyes black hair dark complexion 5 feet 7½ inches high 18 years old Henrico county.
div3.closer:
By order of Col L B Williams H. C Ballou, Lieu and Act Adj't
1st Reg't Va Vols. mh 26--3t*

div3.head: Thirty dollars reward
div3.p: --for the following Deserters, if delivered at Thunder in the city of Richmond, Va.
John N Watson, 23 years of age, 6 feet inches high blue eyes, light hair and light complexion, from Accomac county, Va; sullied in Norfolk, Va.
Pat Mahone, 45 years of age, blue eyes, black hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 6 inches high, an Irishman and substituted in Richmond
M Brady, a substitute in Capt Kyles's company from Apposition county, Va; transferred to company A, 19th battalion Va artillery.
James Grant, 47 years of age, gray eyes dark hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 7 inches high and irishman, and substituted in Richmond; was formerly a member of the Tiger Rifles.

From the 20th battalion Va artillery.
Hugh Marion, 46 years of age. 5 feet 8 inches high hazel eyes sandy hair, light complexion, an Irishman, and substituted in Richmond; Va.
William Carrom, 45 years of age, blue eyes, gray hair, fair complexion, 5 feet 5½ inches high, an irishman, and substituted in Richmond.
Jno Senfot, an Irishman, and substituted in Richmond, Va.
Gno S Shepherd, substituted in Richmond,
Wm H Henchaw, a saddler by trade, substituted in Richmond, Va.
Wm H Howard, 16 years of age, hazel eyes, dark hair, light complexion, 5 feet 4 inches high, from Norfolk, and enlisted as drummer.
These men were transferred from Capt Kyless company, from Appomattox county, Va. to company B, 10th battalion Va artillery.
div3.closer:
A M Reett,
Captain and Chief Quartermaster,
Richmond Defences mh 16--cod5t*

div3.head: Attention, Marylanders.
div3.p:
--The spring has just opened, and now is the time for all men from Maryland to join their own State organization and go to the field.
Your friends at home expect this of you, and your down-trodden State turns to you for protection and makes this demand upon you Come one, come all, to the headquarters of the Maryland Line, corner of 9th and Bank streets and enlist at once in the service of your country
div3.closer:
H E Winder
Captain and Recruiting Officer
for the Maryland Line mh 13--7t*

div3.head: Office of Board of Surpsons for attending sick officers in private quarters.
div3.p: All officers registered as patients in private quarters since the 20th day of January last are hereby notified that unless heard from within ten days after the publication of this notice they will be reported to their respective command are as fit for duty
div3.closer:
A Y P Garnett,
Surgeon
Office corner 11th and Broad sts mh 4--10t

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Deserted, about the 4th of March 1863, Marshall Shiflett, Said Shiflett lives in Bacon Hollow, Green county Va, aged 19 years, 5 feet 7 inches high blue eyes, dark hair, and dark complexion.
For the apprehension and delivery of said Shiflett to his command the above reward will be promptly paid.
div3.closer:
J C Wyant,
Capt Co H, 58th Va Reg't
Camp near Petersburg. Va. mh 12--1w*
